sense.def: a very young child
dictionaryExamples: a baby boy/girl
baby clothes
Sandra had a baby on May 29th.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day Elisa go[es] to work, make[s] dinner for her little baby and watch[es] the T.V. with her husban[d]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian

sense.def: a very young animal
dictionaryExamples: a baby elephant/monkey
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They would take us to see some baby sharks, dolphins, and w[h]ales. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to look after someone's child in their home while they are not there
dictionaryExamples: I babysit for Jane on Tuesday evenings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I am [an] au pair in London and I sometimes [have] to babysit [i]n the evening. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: someone who takes care of your child while you are out
dictionaryExamples: I promised the babysitter that we'd be home by midnight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Write me an e-mail and I will send you the address of the family who needs a babysitter. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: where someone or something was before
dictionaryExamples: When do you go back to school?
I put the can back in the cabinet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She [went] back home at once. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: as a reply or reaction to something
dictionaryExamples: I'm busy at the moment - can I call you back?
I waved to her and she waved back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Write back to me soon. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: in a direction behind you
dictionaryExamples: He sat back on the sofa.
Anna stepped back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cried [out], stepping back and falling down. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to the state something or someone was in before
dictionaryExamples: It's not badly broken - I'm sure we can put it back together again.
Hopefully things will get back to normal soon.
A  thunderstorm woke me, and I couldn't get back to sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My life was back to normal. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: at or to an earlier time
dictionaryExamples: We first met back in 1971.
This tradition dates back to the 16th century.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, it is difficult to get bored in Moscow, where you can see buildings which date back to centur[i]es ago. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a direction away from something
dictionaryExamples: He pulled back the curtain.
The house is set back from the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The action of the book takes place in a lonely inn standing back from the road. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in one direction and then in the opposite direction, often many times
dictionaryExamples: She swayed back and forth to the music.
She drove back and forth between Rochester and New York several times this summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, after much walking back and forth, we found a road, which we followed till we got to the town. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the part of something that is farthest from the front or on the side opposite the front
dictionaryExamples: He wrote her e-mail address down on the back of an envelope.
Our seats were right at the back of the theater.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: My cousins love mermaids, so each sweater has one on the back. 
 Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the part of your body from your shoulders to your bottom
dictionaryExamples: back injuries/pain
I've got a bad back.
He lay on his back, staring at the ceiling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The look on his face stopped me cold, as if someone had just poured freezing water down my back. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: behind someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They sat in back of us on the plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked in back of me and saw my best friend, Malcom, laughing like crazy. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the part of a seat that you lean against when you are sitting
dictionaryExamples: the back of a chair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The back of the sofa is scratched, too. International English Language Testing System; C2; Russian

sense.def: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionaryExamples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to decide to stop having contact with someone or something, or to refuse to help someone
dictionaryExamples: She turned her back on Hollywood and went to live in Florida.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She gets to learn that Olivia turned her back on her past and merged totally with India through her attraction to and sympathy for the Nawab. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: at or near the back of something
dictionaryExamples: a back door/room
the back page/seat
I put it in the back pocket of my jeans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are two movies, but one is for adults so we will see "The back garden". Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small road or street without much traffic and away from the main roads
dictionaryExamples: I prefer to take back roads and avoid the highway traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the museum you have to walk across a pedestrian street, through an unspoiled district, where a jumble of narrow back streets retain old-world character. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to give support or help to a person, plan, or idea
dictionaryExamples: The board refuses to back our plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, without [the] people wh[o] are backing the leader in his fight, he could not achieve his success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to move backward
dictionaryExamples: When the dog growled, she backed away.
He backed the car into a tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When he backed out of the parking lot, he almost crashed into another car. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to move away from someone, usually because you are afraid
dictionaryExamples: I saw he had a knife and backed off immediately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mad Dog would kill him if he tried to back off. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to decide not to do something you had planned or agreed to do
dictionaryExamples: Frank backed out at the last minute, so we had a spare ticket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I met her in the next day, and tried to make an excuse, to back out [of] the deal, but she didn't let me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: back up sb or back sb up

sense.def: to support or help someone
dictionaryExamples: My family backed me up in my fight for compensation.
The last witness backed up what other people had said happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These courses seem to have been popular, perhaps because the teacher of these courses was there to back up and help the students. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: back  up sth or back sth up

sense.def: to prove that something is true
dictionaryExamples: His claims are backed up by recent research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To back up this claim, the case of children who have grown up in orphanages is often cited. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to make an extra copy of something that is held in your computer
dictionaryExamples: Always back up any music you download in case your computer crashes.

sense.def: pain in your back
dictionaryExamples: I had terrible backache last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a backache. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: a person's education, family and experience of life
dictionaryExamples: The school has pupils from many different ethnic/cultural/religious backgrounds.
They come from a wealthy background.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can learn a lot about our cultural background. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: sounds that you can hear that are not the main sounds that you are listening to
dictionaryExamples: background music/noise
If you listen carefully to this piece of music, you can hear a flute in the background.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The exotic food together with oriental music in the background makes you dream of exotic places. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the things that can be seen behind the main things or people in a picture
dictionaryExamples: gold stars on a black background
The artist himself did not paint the backgrounds to his pictures - they were done by his pupils.
He has photographed her against lots of different backgrounds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of nice trees and flowers which I think, would compose an interesting background. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the situation that an event happens in, or things  which have happened in the past which affect it
dictionaryExamples: These decisions are being made against a background of high unemployment.
Can you give me some background on the situation?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The background of the story is life in a small town in one of the southern states of the USA in the early 1930s. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: support, especially money, for a person or plan
dictionaryExamples: financial backing
The proposal has the backing of the mayor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Take some examples throughout history, such as Napoleon, who was very intelligent, and Hitler who, despite being dangerous and evil, had the backing of his country when he spoke to the people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a bag that you carry on your back
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't fit anything else in my backpack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lucy, I have left my backpack in your house. It is very important because there are all my books! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: someone, especially a young person, who travels around an area without spending much money, carrying a backpack
dictionaryExamples: The hostel is used mainly by backpackers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a special offer for backpackers. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when you travel around an area without spending much money, carrying a backpack
dictionaryExamples: I went backpacking when I was a student.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Until now I mainly spent my holidays backpacking through Europe. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: extra help, support or equipment which is available if you need it
dictionaryExamples: Medical staff are on call to provide backup in case of an emergency.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure that most business people have battery back-up and a very good knowledge of when the laptop battery needs to recharge. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a copy of information that is held on a computer, which is stored separately from the computer
dictionaryExamples: Before we leave work each day, we make a backup of all the records we have entered into the computer that day.
The department's backup disks are all stored in a different building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Seems he had made a copy in a special file in a back-up memory. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: toward the direction behind you
dictionaryExamples: I walked backward toward the door.
He took a step backward to allow her to pass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a big park near the place I live, and I think I'll go in-line skating there, rolling forward, c[rui]sing backward and speeding up, enjoying the exciting moment. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to try very hard to do something
dictionaryExamples: They bent over backwards to make us feel at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They won't bend over backwards to look for a quick solution, but sooner or latter the matter will be solved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: less developed or slower to develop than normal
dictionaryExamples: The state needs to reform its backward election laws.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No longer a remote, backward, unimportant country, it became a force to be reckoned with in Europe. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a small area of land behind  a house that is usually covered with grass and may have a fence around it
dictionaryExamples: Growing up, we had a pool and swings in our backyard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My new home is amazing and I love the backyard, it's enormous. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: meat from  a pig cut into long thin slices
dictionaryExamples: a bacon sandwich
a slice of bacon
bacon and eggs
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like bacon very much but I ever eat it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: very small living things that sometimes cause disease
dictionaryExamples: The infection was caused by bacteria in the lung.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were just lucky that during that period, the weather was cold and low temperatures prevented bacteria from spreading. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: unpleasant; causing difficulties or harm
dictionaryExamples: Our vacation was ruined by bad weather.
We've just had some very bad news.
Watch out - he's in a bad mood.
The traffic was so bad that I just came back home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was bad so we stayed in my house. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: of low quality and not acceptable
dictionaryExamples: The food was so bad we couldn't eat it.
He has some very bad habits.
He was sent home from school for bad behavior.
I'm very bad at cooking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided to join this new class because I'm bad [at] English and I want be the best! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: satisfactory
dictionaryExamples: That's not bad for such a small company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The presents are not bad. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to be harmful for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Looking at a computer screen for too long can be bad for your eyes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like playing [on the] computer because it's bad for my eyes. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: very serious or severe
dictionaryExamples: a bad injury
the worst flooding in years
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't go because I have to go to the hospital to see my grandmother who is in very bad health. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not lucky, or not happening how you would like
dictionaryExamples: It was just bad luck that she heard us.
I'll call you later if this is a bad time for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually he [had] bad luck in his exam this time but he can try to do his best next time, can't he? Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to feel guilty or sorry about something that has happened
dictionaryExamples: I felt bad about letting her down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't have anything else which was yours, and I feel so bad about it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that you are sorry about a situation
dictionaryExamples: "He didn't get the job." "Oh, that's too bad."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Too bad you couldn't be here. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: (of people or actions) evil or morally unacceptable
dictionaryExamples: There are a lot of bad people in the world.
He's got his faults but he's not a bad person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew he was a bad man. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: Bad food is not fresh and cannot be eaten.
dictionaryExamples: I think this milk is bad.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My surprise was when I opened the fridge and all the food smelt bad, so I couldn't eat [anything]. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: If you have a bad arm, leg, heart, etc., there is something wrong with it and it is painful.
dictionaryExamples: I've got a bad shoulder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm lugging [my laptop] with me everywhere, with a bad back as a result. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: used to say that nothing can be done to change a situation
dictionaryExamples: I know you don't want to go but it's too bad, we have to.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Human beings have to make their own liv[es] as good as possible, and if they [do] not succeed, the cynical approach is just: too bad! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a piece of metal, plastic,  etc., with words or a picture on it which you wear on your clothes
dictionaryExamples: Everyone at the conference wore a badge with their name on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I saw  the badge he was wearing. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: in a way that is not acceptable or of good quality
dictionaryExamples: They played very badly in the first half.
The event was badly organized.
Their children are extremely badly behaved.
He did badly in his exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had done badly in my last exam and my teacher said she would talk to my mother. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: very much
dictionaryExamples: He needs the money very badly.
They are badly in need of help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need that very badly because I need my five-thousand rupees urgently. Key English Test; A2; Assamese

sense.def: very seriously
dictionaryExamples: badly damaged/hurt/injured
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My brother told me that he crashed into the tree with his car and he [was] badly injured. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: in an unpleasant way
dictionaryExamples: I thought he was treated very badly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past, zoos treated animals quite badly. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a sport for two or four people in which you hit a light object with feathers over a net
dictionaryExamples: We played a game of badminton.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like reading and playing badminton. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: describes a person who becomes angry and annoyed easily
dictionaryExamples: She's very bad-tempered in the morning!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be possible too that you lost your temper and became a bad-tempered man. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a container made of paper, plastic, leather, etc., used for carrying things
dictionaryExamples: a paper/plastic bag
a bag of apples/nuts
He packed his bags and left.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I put my bag in the hall under the chair. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: all the bags that you take with you when you travel
dictionaryExamples: checked/carry-on baggage
We had to pay extra for our excess baggage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [didn't have] much baggage, only one green suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: feelings and experiences from the past that influence how you think and behave now
dictionaryExamples: emotional baggage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover they need to spend it to the best of their abilities trying to bring up a happy person whose behavior will be in harmony with his thoughts and feelings and who will be unencumbered with emotional baggage resulting from lack of love. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to cook something such as bread or a cake with dry heat in an oven
dictionaryExamples: I baked a cake.
freshly baked bread
Bake at 375 degrees for about 20 minutes.
Bake for 5-7 minutes in a preheated oven.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can bake some pizzas and cakes if you want me to. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: someone who makes and sells bread, cakes, etc.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My aunt, who is a baker, can certainly make a big delicious birthday cake for Anna. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a place where bread, cakes, etc. are made or sold
dictionaryExamples: I buy all our bread from the local bakery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best bakery was [on] the other side of town. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: when the weight of someone or something is spread in such a way that they do not fall over
dictionaryExamples: I lost my balance and fell off the bike.
She had to hold onto the railings to keep her balance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I began to go downstairs to the kitchen, [with] two hands on the wall to keep my balance. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when the correct amount of importance is given to each thing so that a situation is successful
dictionaryExamples: We must strike a balance between  police powers and the protection of citizens.
He was concerned that taking on three more men could upset the gender balance in the department.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not easy to find [the] right balance in our lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the amount of money that you still have to pay, or that you have left to use
dictionaryExamples: I always pay off the balance on my credit card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes you [are] surprise[d] when you check the balance of your bank account and then need to cut down your expenses for 2 months. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to give your opinion after you have considered all the facts about something
dictionaryExamples: I think that on balance, I'd prefer to come straight home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On balance, I feel that this annual festival can be even better next year. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to fall because you are leaning too much to one side
dictionaryExamples: He lost his balance and fell down the stairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most exciting part was when we accidently hit a rock and I lost my balance and fell into the cold water. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to give two things the same amount of attention
dictionaryExamples: It's important to strike a balance between spending and saving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything has good and bad sides, the most important thing is to strike a balance. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If something is or hangs in the balance, nobody knows if it will continue to exist in the future or what will happen to it.
dictionaryExamples: The game hung in the balance until the last seconds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my firm belief, that unless we make a step towards the development of our town, its future will hang in the balance and we will ultimately pay the price of our short sightedness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be in a position where you will not fall to either side, or to put something in this position
dictionaryExamples: She was trying to balance a book on her head.
The flamingoes balanced gracefully on one leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have to take many things with you, it will be better to carry th[em] in your car, [rather] than balanc[ing] them on your bicycle. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to give several things equal amounts of importance, time or money so that a situation is successful
dictionaryExamples: I struggle to balance work and family commitments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In life we need to balance all the areas included in human behavior. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a small area joined to the wall outside an upper room where you can stand or sit
dictionaryExamples: We had a drink out on the balcony and watched the sunset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's got a balcony, too, from where I can see the river. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the seats in an upper part of a theater
dictionaryExamples: We had seats in the balcony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The balcony seats reserved for students and young tourists felt like [they were] located on [a steep] cliff, looking down [on] all the heads in the better seats rather than [at] the stage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: with little or no hair on the head
dictionaryExamples: At twenty he was already going bald.
He has a bald spot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Police Officers jumped out from the bushes and subdued the bald man, Lew Juan Yee. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a round object that you throw, kick, or hit in a game, or something with this shape
dictionaryExamples: a beach/golf/tennis ball
She threw a ball at me and I caught it.
Just try to concentrate on hitting/kicking the ball.
a ball of wool
The kitten curled itself into a ball.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They gave me a ball and a T-shirt. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be quick to understand and react to things
dictionaryExamples: She's over ninety, but she's still on the ball.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you're at Sants station, you'll need to be on the ball. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to make something begin or happen
dictionaryExamples: We have to get the ball rolling on this project soon.

sense.def: a type of dancing where carefully organized movements tell a story or express an idea
dictionaryExamples: a ballet dancer
Both children do  ballet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is always making me laugh, and she likes ballet too! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small, colored rubber bag that you blow air into or fill with air until it is round in shape, used for decoration at parties or as a children's toy
dictionaryExamples: We tied balloons and streamers to the ceiling ready for the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the party room there were many balloons. Key English Test; A2; Hindi

sense.def: to forbid something, especially officially
dictionaryExamples: The film was banned in several countries.
She was banned from driving for two years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I think that driving private cars in the main parts of cities should be banned. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an official order that prevents something from happening
dictionaryExamples: There should be a ban on talking loudly in movie theaters.

sense.def: a long curved fruit with a yellow skin
dictionaryExamples: a bunch of bananas
banana milkshake

sense.def: a group of musicians who play modern music together
dictionaryExamples: a jazz/rock band
The Beatles are probably the most famous band in the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can we have a rock band like Etho? Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a thin, flat piece or circle of material put around something or used to hold things together
dictionaryExamples: I have two bands for this watch, one black and one red.

a rubber
                       band
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my wedding ring I am referring to, which was presented to me 3 years ago.  It is a platinum band with 12 tiny diamonds set at regular intervals to go all [a]round. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a long piece of soft cloth that you tie around an injured part of the  body
dictionaryExamples: She had a bandage around her wrist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doctor said that in one week he would take off my bandage and as soon a[s] possible I'll come to visit you. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to make a sudden loud noise or to cause something to do this
dictionaryExamples: She banged her fist angrily on the table.
Outside a door was banging in the wind.
He could hear someone banging at the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One Friday afternoon I was putting away clothes and shoes in the little room which is under the stairs, when my little son, Tom (who was just eighteen months old) banged the door [shut] behind me. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a sudden loud noise
dictionaryExamples: The window slammed shut with a loud bang.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was reading when I suddenly h[e]ard a big bang. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an organization or place where you can borrow money, save money, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I need to go to the bank at lunchtime.
I had to take out a bank loan to start my own business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She works in [a] bank. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi

sense.def: sloping raised land, especially along the sides of a river
dictionaryExamples: By the time we reached the opposite bank, the boat was sinking fast.
These flowers generally grow on river banks and near streams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One bank of the river is stony, the other is sandy. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an arrangement with a bank to keep your money there and to allow you to take it out when you need to
dictionaryExamples: It would be a good idea to open a bank account.
I deposited the money into my bank account this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The man, whose name I can't remember, wrote a serious-looking message in which he [talked about] a money transfer to a Swiss bank account. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: someone with an important position in a bank
dictionaryExamples: She was a successful banker by the time she was forty.

sense.def: the activity of managing the money in your bank accounts
dictionaryExamples: I need to do my banking this afternoon.
A lot of people are shopping and doing their banking online now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Computers are the most modern invention of our societies, they are being used in many fields of our lives, such as banking, in communicating[,] especially in education. International English Language Testing System; B1; Urdu

sense.def: the business of operating a bank
dictionaryExamples: investment/commercial/consumer banking
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to specialize in finance and banking. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: unable to continue in business because you cannot pay your debts
dictionaryExamples: He went bankrupt after only a year in business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the greed for easy money is likely to diminish as many businesses have gone bankrupt these last few months. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a place where especially alcoholic drinks are sold and drunk, or the area in such a place where the person serving the drinks stands
dictionaryExamples: He used to just sit in a bar and listen to jazz.
There weren't any free tables, so I sat at the bar.
Why don't you ask the guy behind the bar?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can bring all my CD's and a very good CD-player, or I can work at the bar. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: a substance that has been made into a solid, rectangular shape
dictionaryExamples: a bar of soap
a chocolate bar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I've got the right present for your cousins. What do you think about a bar of chocolate from Switzerland? First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a straight stick made of metal

sense.def: used to give the first important reason for something
dictionaryExamples: To begin with, we can't afford to move.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To begin with, it doesn't pollute and I think it's time we started thinking about [the] environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who is starting to do or learn something for the first time
dictionaryExamples: I'm a complete beginner at yoga.
This judo class is for beginners only.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The book must have the vo[cabulary] for [a] beginner. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: the first part of something or the start of something
dictionaryExamples: We met at the beginning of 1998.
She sat down and read the book straight through from beginning to end.
I enjoyed my job at/in the beginning, but I'm bored with it now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the beginning of the party, we danced and sang. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: to do or say things in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: She always behaves badly at bedtime.
He's been behaving very strangely recently.
You behaved like an idiot!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As always, I'll behave like a gentleman. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be polite and not make a situation difficult
dictionaryExamples: Did the children behave (themselves)?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Team sports can also help children to behave themselves. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the way that you behave
dictionaryExamples: bad/good behavior
Did you notice anything strange about his behavior?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But he answered my e-mail [where] I was apologizing for my behavior at his party, [but] he was really upset with me because I dropped his birthday cake into the pool and everyone laughed. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Close the door behind you.
Their office is behind the main building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think [we should meet] in front of the restaurant, behind the library. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: slower or less successful than someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The project is already behind schedule.
Baltimore is still three games behind Milwaukee.
The tests are used to identify students who are falling behind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have already told Lissa, and she'll lend me her copy book so I don't get behind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: giving your help or support to someone
dictionaryExamples: The group is 100 percent behind her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is very nice because if you have problems he is always behind you to help you. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: in prison
dictionaryExamples: Until the court hearing, they will remain behind bars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He confessed that he was guilty and was put behind bars. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: causing something, or responsible for something
dictionaryExamples: What was the reason behind her decision to leave?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another reason behind this kind of thinking is that some boys feel a[w]kward when they see girls and they think they are being ignored in the class. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: not fashionable or modern
dictionaryExamples: Dad's a bit behind the times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [should] improve our equipment. Otherwise we will be behind the times. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: If a bad experience or your own bad behavior is behind you, it does not exist or affect your life now.
dictionaryExamples: He's put his troubled past behind him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have got to put the past behind us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If you do something behind someone's back, you do it without them knowing, often in an unfair way.
dictionaryExamples: Have they been saying things about me behind my back?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The food must be perfect, too, or else her mother-in-law and my father's sisters will think that she's not a proper wife, and will probably say insulting things about her behind her back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: privately and not in public
dictionaryExamples: Most of the deals were made behind closed doors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If something happens behind the scenes, it happens secretly.
dictionaryExamples: A lot of hard work has been going on behind the scenes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ms. Bolam knew a lot of things going on behind the scenes, [which were] not [known to] the patients. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Somebody grabbed me from behind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An old man appeared from behind wearing the same clothes [as] the owner of the phone and asked [her] for it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: slower or later than someone else, or than you should be
dictionaryExamples: She's behind on the rent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those children who do not get this at home are the ones who are behind in their schoolwork. International English Language Testing System; B2; Hindi

sense.def: when you believe that something is true or real
dictionaryExamples: a popular/common/widespread belief
He asked her in the belief that she would lend him the money.
It is my personal belief that the public have a right to know.
She took this medicine in the mistaken belief that it would cure her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At this time, tango was considered an immoral type of music; but Carlos Gardel changed this belief, [and] people from all over the world loved him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an idea that you are certain is true
dictionaryExamples: He made no secret of his belief that she would recover.
philosophical beliefs
All nonviolent religious and political beliefs should be respected equally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We get to know the beliefs, superstitions or the principles of other religious denominations. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the feeling that someone or something is effective or right
dictionaryExamples: a belief in social justice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With our hectic lifestyles and complacent belief in modern medical sciences we may forget about the importance of proper eating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: to think that something is true, or that what someone says is true
dictionaryExamples: They believe that their health has suffered because of the chemicals.
I can't believe she wants to go out with me.
I told you she was there but you wouldn't believe me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe him. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to think something, without being completely sure
dictionaryExamples: "Is she coming alone?" "I believe so."
All the crew are missing, believed dead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe it is in your bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be very surprised when you see someone or something, or when you hear what someone says
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't believe my ears when Dan said they were getting married.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, this church was extremely simple [o]n the outside, but when I got inside it, I couldn't believe my eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that something is true although it seems surprising
dictionaryExamples: He even remembered my birthday, believe it or not.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I visited the "Roman Bath'' which is more than 2000 years old and, believe it or not, it still works! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be certain that something exists
dictionaryExamples: Do you believe in ghosts?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Claire I want to tell you that we have to believe in miracles! Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to be confident that something is effective and right
dictionaryExamples: He believes in saying what he thinks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays I don't believe in changing your decision. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an electrical object that makes a ringing sound when you press a button
dictionaryExamples: Please ring the bell for attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was relaxing at home when suddenly the bell rang. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a hollow, metal object, shaped like a cup, that makes a ringing sound when you hit it
dictionaryExamples: the sound of church bells ringing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I heard the bells from the tower. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: If a word, especially a name, rings a bell, you think you have heard it before.
dictionaryExamples: Shane Watson? That name rings a bell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its name is Laser - I suppose it rings a bell? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something belongs somewhere, that is the place it should be in.
dictionaryExamples: This table belongs in the living room.
These papers belong with the others.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can understand people wh[o] say that animals belong in nature. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to feel happy or comfortable in a situation
dictionaryExamples: I spent two years in Boston but I never felt that I belonged there.

sense.def: If something belongs to you, you own it.
dictionaryExamples: This book belongs to Sarah.
You shouldn't take what doesn't belong to you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need it back because it belongs to my cousin. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to be a member of a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: We belong to the same tennis club.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, I belonged to [a] golf club when I went to university in Japan. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the things that a person owns, especially those which can be carried
dictionaryExamples: I put a few personal belongings in a bag and left the house for the last time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Five different kings have lived there with their families and it is possible to see several of their personal belongings. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: in a lower position than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: From the top of the skyscraper the cars below us looked like insects.
Send your answers to the address  below.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's a nice place, because you have a great view of the other mountains and the country below you. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: less than a particular amount or level
dictionaryExamples: His marks in English have been below average for some time now.
The temperature has fallen below zero/freezing recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to learn that [it] is not natural for a lion [to be] living in a country where, in winter, [the] temperature can fall below zero. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: lower in rank
dictionaryExamples: Monica is a grade below me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [With] him being only 37 years old and [having] been promoted to the second level below the board of directors of a well-known international company, he seems like a good example [of] a successful person, at least in this area of success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a long, thin piece of leather, cloth, or plastic that you wear around your waist
dictionaryExamples: She buckled/fastened her belt around her waist.
He had eaten so much that he had to undo his belt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Juliana gave me a pink belt. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to spend less money
dictionaryExamples: Since I lost my job we've all had to tighten our belts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All this costs money and where do we get this extra money from but from the tax payers, who once again have to tighten their belts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a long seat for two or more people, usually made of wood or metal
dictionaryExamples: a park bench
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At 1 p.m. Paul was sitting on a bench and waiting for Julia. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to move your body or part of your body so that it is not straight
dictionaryExamples: Bend your knees when lifting heavy objects.
She bent down to pick up the pen.
Now, bend forwards/over and touch your toes!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend was bending over the table laughing hysterically. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to (cause to) curve
dictionaryExamples: The trees were bending in the wind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw fir trees bending in half and 500-year-old oaks shedding their leaves. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to try very hard to do something
dictionaryExamples: They bent over backwards to make us feel at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They won't bend over backwards to look for a quick solution, but sooner or latter the matter will be solved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a curved part of something
dictionaryExamples: There's a bend in the pipe so you can't see from one end to the other.
There's a sharp bend in the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other car disappeared around a sharp bend and when we came [a]round it, we saw that the car had stopped in the middle of the road. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: under something, or in a lower position than something
dictionaryExamples: Jeremy hid the letter beneath a pile of papers.
After weeks at sea, it was wonderful to feel firm ground beneath our feet once more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She could feel the train coming because the ground beneath her feet was moving. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not good enough or of not enough importance for you notice or to spend you time on
dictionaryExamples: He thinks housework is beneath him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He hadn't reali[z]ed how much he would miss the high-life until he was forced to watch all the rich and famous people come into the restaurant and look down [on] everything and everyone who was beneath them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: helpful, useful or good
dictionaryExamples: The improvement in sales figures had a beneficial effect on the company as a whole.
Exercise is beneficial to/for almost everyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, team sports are beneficial to children so if the schools they attend do not have any, they should take up [something]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that helps you or gives you an advantage
dictionaryExamples: The discovery of oil brought many benefits to the town.
One of the many benefits of foreign travel is learning how to cope with the unexpected.
He's had the benefit of an expensive education and yet he continues to work as a waiter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking everything [into] account, the drawbacks far outweigh its benefits. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a helpful service employees receive in addition to their pay
dictionaryExamples: health/medical benefits
The personnel director outlined the employee benefits -- health insurance, retirement plan, etc.

blocks.phrase: give sb the benefit of the doubt

sense.def: to choose to believe what someone tells you even though it may be wrong or a lie
dictionaryExamples: She says her train was late, so I suppose we'd better give her the benefit of the doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time our parents tell us ".. have you thought about it, are you sure you are not making a mistake?" we just answer "sure I have, no problem." Next time they do, let's give them the benefit of the doubt and let's think twice about the subject. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: for sb's/sth's benefit / for the benefit of sb/sth

sense.def: in order to help someone
dictionaryExamples: We bought the piano for the children's benefit.
She wanted her money to be used for the benefit of poor children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Needless to say, I hope you take into consideration all [of] this, not only for Gustavo's benefit, but also for the benefit of the astronaut training program and the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be helped by something or to help someone
dictionaryExamples: I feel that I have benefited greatly from her experience.
How can we benefit those who most need our help?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure that the café would benefit a great deal from a non-smoking-area. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a small round fruit on particular plants and trees
dictionaryExamples: I usually scatter a few berries on my muesli.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day we were swimming, fishing, picking mushro[om]s and berries, hunting and making fires to prepare food. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: next to someone or something, or very near them
dictionaryExamples: Come and sit here beside me.
Our school was built right beside a river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We shall go shopping after the film because the shopping complex is beside the cinema. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: to experience a powerful emotion
dictionaryExamples: He was beside himself  when he found out his dog had died.
He was beside himself with rage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Spending one's spare time being beside oneself with anger scarcely ever makes holidays [enjoy]able. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: in addition to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Do you play any other sports besides football and basketball?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a Chinese food buffet but besides Chinese food they also have Italian food like pizza. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to give another reason for something
dictionaryExamples: She won't mind your being late - besides, it's hardly your fault.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I'm going to buy "Troy" because it looks to me [to be] a great movie - besides, it reminds me of your vacations in Mexico. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in addition to
dictionaryExamples: Besides looking after the children, she runs a successful business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But besides playing, you can also sit [i]n the "club lounge", where you can drink something with your friends or just play cards. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: (superlative of good) better than any other
dictionaryExamples: She was my best friend.
This is the best meal I've ever had.
He's one of our best students.
Are you sure this is the best way of doing it?
Your parents only want what is best for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes [to] meet me every day because we are best friend[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: something that you write at the end of a letter
dictionaryExamples: With best wishes, Anna
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With best wishes, Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: the thing that is best, if you cannot have or do the thing you really want
dictionaryExamples: Coaching baseball is the next best thing to playing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For many working people, there is hardly time to cook and prepare your dinner, so the next best thing is to rush into a M[cD]onalds' or Burger King. International English Language Testing System; C1; Yapese

sense.def: Someone’s best bet is the action most likely to be successful.
dictionaryExamples: If you want to get to the theater on time, your best bet is to get a cab.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The international cuisine chef can whip up some delicious creations from time to time; but your best bet is to go for one of the delicious steaks served. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: (superlative of well) most, or more than any other
dictionaryExamples: Which of the songs did you like best?
They were the best-dressed couple at the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like Australia best. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: (superlative of well) in the most suitable or satisfactory way
dictionaryExamples: I sleep best with the window open.
The Grand Canyon is best seen at sunset when it seems to change color.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be best if you c[a]me on Wednesday 27th. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to be the most suitable person to have responsibility and make important decisions
dictionaryExamples: When it comes to dealing with my own son, I think I know best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How true is that expression "Father knows best." If my father [was alive] today he would probably be laughing his head off. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that you hope someone will be happy, healthy, successful, etc., often when saying goodbye
dictionaryExamples: Well, all the best - it was nice meeting you.
Please wish him all the best in his new job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to wish you all the best! Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: someone or something that is better than any other
dictionaryExamples: I like all of Hitchcock's films, but I think "Notorious" is the best.
Chris and I are the best of friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The trip was the best I have ever been [on] in my life. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: at the highest level of achievement or quality
dictionaryExamples: The article is an example of journalism at its best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoyed this trip because we got to stay in the countryside and [see] nature at its very best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make the greatest effort possible
dictionaryExamples: I did my best to persuade him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And the police said that they will try their best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to try to be positive about a situation you do not like but cannot change
dictionaryExamples: Our hotel room is pretty small, but we'll just have to make the best of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately I don't have very much spare time so we will have to arrange it carefully in order to make the best of your time in London. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to have the advantages of two different situations
dictionaryExamples: Living in the country and working in the city you have the best of both worlds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only those that can afford to live in the suburban areas can combine the best of both worlds and they tend to be rather affluent. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to show that the most positive way of considering something is still not good
dictionaryExamples: If he drops the course now, at best he’ll get an incomplete, and he could fail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Then, due to the social standards, the old find themselves being abandoned and helpless. At best, such people are hospitalized. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionaryExamples: Moving to a smaller apartment really was for the best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

blocks.phrase: bring out the best in sb

sense.def: to cause someone's best qualities to show
dictionaryExamples: This chance to work with young people has really brought out the best in him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: TV can be a babysitter, but such a relationship is not going to bring out the best in a child. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used to show that something is not good when it is the best it can be
dictionaryExamples: He's not exactly patient at the best of times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They knew that even at the best of times he looked unpleasant but now he was of [a] completely different [appearance]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a very popular book that many people have bought
dictionaryExamples: His latest book is likely to be another bestseller.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe your parents could bring me one of the newest bestsellers, which haven't been translated [in]to Polish yet. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to behave in a dishonest or cruel way to someone who trusts you
dictionaryExamples: She felt betrayed by her mother's lack of support.
He promised never to betray her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He couldn't believe that his best friend had betrayed him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: (comparative of good) of a higher quality, more effective, or more enjoyable than something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: She found a better job.
The movie was better than I expected.
She is a lot better at tennis than I am.
If you cook it this way it's much better.
Relations between the two countries have never been better.
He stood near the front to get a better view.
The situation is getting better all the time.
The longer you keep this wine, the better it tastes.
The bed was hard, but it was better than nothing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a better pen than others. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: healthy, or less ill than before
dictionaryExamples: Do you feel better now?
Is your stomach ache better?
I hope you get better soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I visited my cousin last night in the hospital he was ill. He is now better. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to look old or be   in bad condition because of a lot of use
dictionaryExamples: This jacket has seen better days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the dense fog he managed to see a man standing nearby, whose clothes ha[d] definitely seen better days. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: (comparative of well) to a greater degree, or in a more successful or more effective way
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to get to know him better.
Helen did much better than I did in the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But she expl[ained everything] very clear[ly], so I understood better. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

blocks.phrase: I/you/he, etc. had better do sth

sense.def: used to say what someone should do
dictionaryExamples: You'd better hurry or you'll miss the train.
He'd better not be late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'd better bring a notebook. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to have enough experience not to do something stupid or something that will not achieve anything
dictionaryExamples: I thought she'd listen to me - I should have known better.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surely two grown-ups should have known better than to shout at each other at the top of their lungs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in the space that separates two places, people or objects
dictionaryExamples: The town lies halfway between Rome and Florence.
Standing between the two adults was a small child.
A narrow alley ran between the two houses.
She squeezed in between her sisters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I left it in your bedroom, [o]n the shelf between your bed and your brother's. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: in the period of time that separates two different events or times
dictionaryExamples: You shouldn't eat between meals.
There is a ten minute break between classes.
The ticket office closes between 12:30 and 1:30 for lunch hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: involving two or more groups of people
dictionaryExamples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to go shopping and then see the match between Spain and Germany. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show the largest and smallest amount or level of something
dictionaryExamples: The box weighs between 55 and 60 pounds.
The competition is open to children between six and twelve years old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali

sense.def: connecting two or more places, things or people
dictionaryExamples: There is regular train service between Philadelphia and Washington.

sense.def: separating two places or things
dictionaryExamples: The wall between East and West Berlin came down in 1989.
The gap between the rich and the poor has increased dramatically over the past decade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the most interesting place near my town is [the] mountains [which are] like a wall between my country and China. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: among two or more people or things
dictionaryExamples: We drank two bottles of wine between four of us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If you read between the lines, you understand what something really means when it hasn't been directly said or written.
dictionaryExamples: Reading between the lines, it was obvious that something was wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All songs send positive thoughts and messages to listeners, although sometimes you really have to read between the lines to understand this profound message. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in the space that separates two people, places, or things
dictionaryExamples: The wood is in neat piles with newspaper placed in between.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a shuttle bus from the airport straight to the main station with only one stop in between. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: in the period of time that separates two events or times
dictionaryExamples: There's a train at 6:15 and one at 10:30 but nothing in between.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, there [is] research that prove[s] that people cannot work for more than two hours [at a time]. They can't concentrate that long [and] they need to rest their minds for short periods in between. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: not happening or existing very often
dictionaryExamples: Opportunities like this are few and far between.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jobs in those days were few and far between and for a number of years he was alternating between temporary jobs and unemployment benefit[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used in order to warn someone to be careful
dictionaryExamples: Beware of the dog.
In grassy areas, beware of insects like ticks that bite carry disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it's fun to surf, beware of the danger... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: continuing after a particular time or date
dictionaryExamples: Few people live beyond the age of a hundred.
We cannot allow the work to continue beyond the end of the year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should take a [break] every two hours  because, beyond two hours, your mind cannot record what you are learning. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: on the other side of something
dictionaryExamples: Beyond the river is a small town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly she recognized something red, beyond a tree and covered with some leaves. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not able to be changed by me/us, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Tonight's performance has been cancelled due to circumstances beyond our control.

Learner example: As I work as a bilingual secretary in a multinational company, I use English regularly.

sense.def: a group of people or things within particular lower and higher limits

sense.def: the body part inside your  head that controls thought, memory, feelings and activity

brain injury/damage
brain cells
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: The class starts at 3:00 and ends at 4:00.  You don't need to bring any thing but yourself; your clothes and your brain. 
 Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: used to refer to intelligence
dictionaryExamples: She's the brains behind our software development.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would have to do my best to teach my children how to use their brains more instead of using technology system like computer. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: the part of a vehicle that makes it stop or move  more slowly

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has 24 active gears and multilink kevlor brakes. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to make a vehicle stop or move more slowly

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The motorcyclist cut in dangerously, so we had to brake. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: one of several stores, offices, etc. that are  part of a company or organization

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has come from our branch office in New York, where he worked as [an] assistant. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a part of a subject

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My computer brand is Acer. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: completely new
dictionaryExamples: The washing machine is brand new.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dark marble is easy to keep clean and the solid brass handles look luxur[ious]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: the group of musical instruments made from brass
dictionaryExamples: a brass band
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I liked it so much that I decided to become a brass band musician myself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They all laughed at me, but I was brave enough to mount the horse again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: in a brave way

a loaf of bread
white/wheat/rye bread
sliced bread
fresh/stale bread

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like bread,  rice and bean[s]. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to separate into two or more pieces or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: The dish fell to the floor and broke.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I  broke a beautiful glass. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to damage a bone in your arm/leg, etc.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like [a new mobile phone] because the other one ha[s] broken. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: George was looking outside when something broke the silence. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

dictionaryExamples: Usain Bolt broke the world record for the 200 meters.

sense.def: to not do what you should do

sense.def: to make people feel more relaxed in a social situation

sense.def: to make as much money as you spent, but no more
dictionaryExamples: The company only managed to break even this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Company C does not seem to be doing well. In the year 2000, it just seems to be breaking even.International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: If news or a story breaks, or if someone breaks it, it becomes known by the public for the first time.
dictionaryExamples: News of the scandal broke just before the election.

sense.def: to tell someone about something new or important
dictionaryExamples: When they broke the news of their engagement, their parents were was delighted.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't hard to understand why she was filled with delight and happiness when her manager broke the news. The company was opening a new branch in Miami and they wanted her to become the director there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to escape from someone or something that is controlling you

sense.def: to suddenly escape or become separate from something or someone

blocks.phrasalVerb: break in or break into sth

sense.def: to get into a building or car using force, usually to steal something

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I even thought a burglar might have broken into my house and was going to kill me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to end (something) suddenly
dictionaryExamples: She broke off in the middle of a sentence.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you remember, my car didn't work as well as it should and I had to break off my [trip].First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

dictionaryExamples: War broke out in 1914.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately everything was stopped because [the] Second World War broke out. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to force your way through something that is holding you back

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must bring an old shirt, pencils, water and some food for the break. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a vacation or period of time away from work, school, etc.

sense.def: where something has cracked or separated into pieces
dictionaryExamples: A break in a water pipe caused a flood.
a break in the bone

sense.def: a lucky opportunity
dictionaryExamples: His big break came when he was offered a part in a TV series.

sense.def: easy to break
dictionaryExamples: That vase is breakable so be careful.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of that I almost end[ed] up in hospital suffering [a] nervous breakdown. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

International English Language Testing System; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: the food you eat in the morning after you wake up

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Future homes might not be built out of bricks at all! First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: using only a few words
dictionaryExamples: world news in brief
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I will tell you in brief what exactly happened to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: for a short time
dictionaryExamples: We chatted briefly about the weather.

sense.def: strong in color
dictionaryExamples: Leslie always wears bright colors.
He said hello and I felt my face turn bright red.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be using bright orange for my bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: full of light, shining
dictionaryExamples: bright sunshine

The lights are too bright in here - they're hurting my eyes.

sense.def: clever
dictionaryExamples: They were bright children, always asking questions.

dictionaryExamples: You're very bright and cheery this morning!

dictionaryExamples: Look on the bright side - no one was badly hurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am quite self-confident and I usually look on the bright side, as I am not [interested in] pessimistic thoughts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: with a lot of strong color or light
dictionaryExamples: brightly colored clothes
a brightly lit room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sun was shining brightly over the white mountain tops. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: extremely intelligent or very skillful
dictionaryExamples: a brilliant mathematician
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is [an] engineering student and he is brilliant in his stud[ies].  Preliminary English Test; B1; Indonesian

sense.def: full of light or color
dictionaryExamples: The sky was a brilliant blue.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please bring old clothes with you. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

dictionaryExamples: It was a very moving speech, and it brought a lump to my throat.

blocks.phrasalVerb: bring back sth or bring sth back

sense.def: to return from somewhere with something
dictionaryExamples: Can you bring me back some milk?

blocks.phrasalVerb: bring out sth or bring sth out

sense.def: to produce something to sell to the public
dictionaryExamples: They've just brought out a new, smaller phone.

blocks.phrasalVerb: bring up sb or bring sb up
