Their house is on a very busy street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite the fact that Rome is a busy city, you can find quiet place[s] like Broccian lake and the seaside in Ostia. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: In a busy period, you have a lot of things to do.
dictionaryExamples: I've got a busy week ahead of me.
Take a rest - you've had a busy day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a busy day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to introduce an added statement, usually something that is different from what you have said before
dictionaryExamples: You can invite Keith to the party, but please don't ask that friend of his.
She's very hard-working but not very imaginative.
She's not only a painter but also a writer.
I think it's true, but then, I'm no expert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are eight rooms but the best one is my bedroom, because there are a lot of books. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: used before you say why something will not or did not happen or is not true
dictionaryExamples: I was going to go to his party, but I was ill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm really sorry I haven't written for so long, but I was very busy last week. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: except
dictionaryExamples: Everyone knows but Andrew.
This car has been nothing but trouble - it's always breaking down!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm free all days of the week but Monday and Wednesday. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: almost
dictionaryExamples: The movie was all but over by the time we got there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He could all but hear their stomachs rumble. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a person who sells meat in a store
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He  start[ed] to work as a butcher. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: the part of your body that you sit on
dictionaryExamples: The baby is learning to walk and keeps falling on her butt.

sense.def: to interrupt or join in a conversation or activity when the other people do not want you to
dictionaryExamples: The interviewer kept butting in and wouldn't let me answer the question.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Was it a big one, Granny?", the little girl butt[ed] in. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a pale yellow food made from cream that you put on bread or use in cooking
dictionaryExamples: Have some bread and butter.
a butter dish
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have fresh farm food like butter, milk, chees[e]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: an insect with large, patterned wings
dictionaryExamples: A butterfly landed on her sleeve for a moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were lot[s] of wild flowers and we saw some beautiful birds and butterflies. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: a switch that you press to control a piece of equipment
dictionaryExamples: He inserted the DVD and pressed the "play" button.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could have written a letter in a bottle but waiting for the answer would take a decade, now [with e-mail] it's just a click of a button. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: a small, round object used to fasten something, for example a shirt or coat
dictionaryExamples: I need to sew a new button on my blouse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a long dress with some square buttons [on the] front of it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to get something by paying money for it
dictionaryExamples: Eventually she had saved enough money to buy a small car.
They bought the house for $240,000.
He's buying flowers for his mother.
I bought my camera from a friend of mine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought it five years ago. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: someone who buys something expensive such as a house
dictionaryExamples: He's still looking for a buyer for his house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had already found a buyer for the famous painting. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling of excitement, energy, or pleasure
dictionaryExamples: He gets a real buzz from going to the gym.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reading groups will then create a real buzz in the community in regard to reading. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hebrew

sense.def: a continuous sound like a bee makes
dictionaryExamples: I could hear the buzz of a fly near my ear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was working when I started hearing a kind of buzz, that was getting louder and louder. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a continuous noise like a bee
dictionaryExamples: I can hear something buzzing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are now sitting quietly at their desks in a classroom where you can hear the flies buzz. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be full of activity and excitement
dictionaryExamples: The crowd was buzzing with excitement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Summer was getting into full swing and the city was buzzing with activity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: used to show the person or thing that does something
dictionaryExamples: She  was examined by a doctor.
We were amazed by what she told us.
I'm reading some short stories (written) by Chekhov.
The book was translated by a well-known author.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to read the "House of Terror" by Constanza Vanges, [which] is about strange things that start happening in a house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show how something is done
dictionaryExamples: They traveled across Europe by train/car.
She did the decorating (all) by herself.
Do you want to be paid in cash or by check?
He learned English by listening to the radio.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go there by bus. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: not later than; at/on or before
dictionaryExamples: She promised to be back by five o'clock.
The application must be in by August 31st.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please come tomorrow by 3 o'clock in the afternoon to paint my bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used when you say something new or on a different subject
dictionaryExamples: I think we've discussed everything we need to - by the way, what time is it?
Oh, by the way, my name's Julie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the way, I want to buy a raincoat for my brother. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: near or next to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: A small child stood by her side.
I'll meet you by the post office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the best solution could be [to] put a desk by the window because I'll have natur[a]l light and a double bed next to the door. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: as a result of an accident, mistake, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I went to the wrong room by mistake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was putting my shopping bags on the table and I pushed it by mistake. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: done or made by a person instead of a machine
dictionaryExamples: This sweater has to be washed by hand.

sense.def: holding a particular part of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She grabbed me by the arm.

sense.def: by a great amount
dictionaryExamples: They are by far the best students in the class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have traveled to many countries, but New Zealand is by far the best. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: so that you can remember all of something
dictionaryExamples: We had to learn the whole poem by heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know all his songs by heart and I was singing all the time. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

blocks.phrase: day by day/little by little/one by one, etc.

sense.def: used in particular phrases to mean "gradually" or "in units of"
dictionaryExamples: Day by day he grew stronger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather gets warmer and warmer day by day and no one miss[es] the rain and the severe cold of winter. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to show measurements or amounts
dictionaryExamples: The room measures 15 feet by 20 feet.
Interest rates have been increased by 0.25%.
I'm paid by the hour.
Copies have sold by the million.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore you will see that this festival attracts people by the truckload. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: as said by a lot of people
dictionaryExamples: The party was, by all accounts, a great success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have known Michael Van Cleef for over two decades now, and he is, by all accounts, an exemplary worker. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: in general
dictionaryExamples: By and large, people have welcomed the changes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By and large, it is clear that we all enjoy some kind of sport. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: If you have to do something by law, it is illegal not to do it.
dictionaryExamples: They have to provide a contract by law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They consist in preparing e-mails or letters, all formal, giving explanations to clients about their fiscal situation in Brazil, preparing and calculating tax returns, providing to [the] IRS our clients asset positions, which is required by law and also, having meetings with clients - this is the most important and exciting part of our work. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: by no means; not by any means

sense.def: not in any way
dictionaryExamples: I'm not an expert by any means.
It is by no means clear what the mayor can do to end the strike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For one thing, the fight against air pollution is by no means an easy mission. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: as a type of something
dictionaryExamples: He sent me some flowers by way of apology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Academy however provided nothing whatsoever by way of entertainment, though with a group of interesting young people and a little imagination this should not be a pro[b]lem. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to do something exactly according to the rules
dictionaryExamples: The lawyers want to make sure we've done everything strictly by the book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The upper-class people always do things by the book, follow the rules and the conventions and therefore are stand-offish and cold. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something that you say when you are agreeing to let someone do something
dictionaryExamples: I have a copy of the report on my desk. By all means have a look at it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The kitchen utensils stay next to the sink. You can make use of them by all means. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: by one person telling another telling you
dictionaryExamples: Students learned of the center by word of mouth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past news traveled mostly by word of mouth and it took days and sometimes weeks before a person would become aware of an occurrence on the other end of the world. International English Language Testing System; C2; English

sense.def: in a similar way
dictionaryExamples: You have to let people know your plans in good time and, by the same token, they should give you some advance warning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our college will only benefit from this event as long as it give[s] a nice and memorable impression. By the same token, we should all be well prepared and visualise beforehand possible manoeuvres that could appear, so that we can control the situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: because of something
dictionaryExamples: She succeeded by virtue of hard work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, you should take into consideration the expenses, which might be exorbitant by virtue of the fact that you inten[d] to create places with a beautiful ambience and a wide range of comforts offered that will facilitate residents' lives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: goodbye
dictionaryExamples: Bye! We'll see you soon.
Are you going? Bye now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bye, see you soon. Key English Test; A2; Spanish
